TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in ORG . She is represented before the ORG by Mr I. Furmann , a lawyer practising in PERSON , who also assists “ ORG for ORG ” ( hereafter the “ ORG ” ) . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , Deputy ORG - Secretary , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant is of GPE origin , as was her late husband , Mr GPE .
The other person involved in the case , PERSON was born in DATE . In DATE he joined ORG . Following DATE training , he received his firearm in DATE .
On DATE at TIME , accompanied by an accomplice , broke the window of a car parked QUANTITY from FAC in GPE and stole the radio .

That night Sergeant L.T. was on guard in front of the ORG . Having noticed Mr GPE and his accomplice , he left his sentry - box . Seeing a police officer in uniform approach , Mr PERSON handed the car radio to his accomplice and both men started to run .

PERSON ordered them to stop . Mr PERSON and his accomplice looked back but kept running . PERSON drew a gun and started to pursue them from a distance of QUANTITY . During the chase , he saw a shiny object in the hand of CARDINAL of the fugitives . In a nearby street he again ordered them to stop . When they failed to do so , he fired a warning shot . Some time later he again ordered them to stop and fired a second warning shot . After QUANTITY , PERSON lost sight of them . Following a tip - off from an eye - witness ( E. B. ) , PERSON went through the gateway to a house in order to search for them .

The gateway opened up onto a yard which was crossed by a path . To the right of the path , there was a garden ; the entrance door to the building was located to the left of the path . Mr PERSON hid himself by the entrance door ; his accomplice was lying in the garden . The visibility in the yard , which was not lit , was QUANTITY . PERSON crossed the path holding his firearm in his right hand . As PERSON passed by , PERSON , leaning forward , made a sudden move towards him . PERSON stepped aside , turned towards Mr GPE and – holding his firearm at a height of QUANTITY – fired a non - targeted shot at him from a distance of QUANTITY .

The bullet entered the right side of Mr PERSON 's chest between the sixth and seventh rib , in a downward direction . It passed through the liver and exited through the tenth rib , finally lodging itself in the entrance door at a height of QUANTITY .

Mr PERSON collapsed . PERSON got his handcuffs ready , but having noticed that Mr PERSON 's injuries were serious he decided that it was not necessary to use them . At this point the eye - witness PERSON arrived . PERSON asked him to call an ambulance and continued his search for PERSON accomplice .
The ambulance arrived and transported Mr PERSON to ORG at TIME where he underwent surgery . On DATE he died due to circulatory and respiratory failure caused by haemorrhagic shock .

Meanwhile , on DATE at TIME the police inspected the scene of the incident and arrested PERSON accomplice who was still hiding in the grass . Outside the house where the incident took place , they found the CARDINAL spent cartridges from the warning shots ; the spent cartridge from the lethal shot was found in the yard , as was the stolen radio .

On DATE PERSON reported the events to the Head of ORG . He maintained that , during the chase and , again , immediately before firing the lethal shot , he had seen a shiny object in PERSON hand . He had perceived the latter 's sudden move away from the door towards him as an attack , probably with a knife . He further deposed that he had intended to shoot PERSON in his thigh in self - defence .

Subsequently , administrative proceedings were instituted against PERSON with a view to examining the lawfulness of his use of his weapon . The opinion of a forensic weapons expert was also obtained . On DATE the Head of ORG discontinued these proceedings on the ground that “ according to the information obtained , the police officer had used his firearm lawfully and professionally ” . In the decision , it was established that although PERSON shot had been aimed at Mr PERSON 's thigh , Mr PERSON had in fact been hit on the trunk , because he had been in the act of descending the stairs leading from the entrance door .

On DATE the applicant , represented by Mr ORG , lodged a complaint challenging the administrative decision . In reaction to this complaint , ORG suspended the proceedings pending the outcome of the criminal proceedings initiated against PERSON ( see below ) . Following PERSON acquittal , ORG discontinued the administrative proceedings on DATE . The applicant was informed of this decision .

Subsequent to PERSON death , a second administrative procedure was opened in order to establish the circumstances of the death . On DATE an autopsy was carried out by CARDINAL forensic pathologists . On DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings , having regard to the competent authority 's conclusion that PERSON use of his firearm had been lawful and to the finding that there was no appearance of any medical negligence in the treatment administered to PERSON . The applicant was informed of this decision .

Subsequently , criminal proceedings were instituted against PERSON on a charge of homicide . On DATE Mr PERSON requested ORG of ORG to inform him about the state of these proceedings . On DATE Mr ORG submitted to ORG a power of attorney signed by PERSON mother .

Meanwhile , a reporter and a cameraman from NORP Television who had been working at the scene of the incident on DATE submitted a video and an audiotape recording of a conversation with PERSON accomplice about a knife found lying on the ground nearby . Both men were heard as witnesses on DATE and CARDINAL DATE , respectively .

CARDINAL further witnesses were heard on DATE . CARDINAL of them ( PERSON ) was the eye - witness who had given the tip - off to PERSON and had been asked by PERSON to call an ambulance ; the other ( FAC ) lived in the house where the incident occurred .
On DATE Mr ORG submitted CARDINAL expert opinions which had been prepared at the request of the ORG .
On DATE ORG appointed a forensic medical expert who submitted his opinion on DATE .
On DATE ORG appointed a forensic weapons expert who submitted his opinion on DATE . The opinion was based on an on - site demonstration .
On DATE ORG deposed that it had been called at TIME on TIME of the incident . On DATE and DATE the ambulance driver , the doctor and her assistant were heard as witnesses .
On DATE Mr GPE 's accomplice failed to appear at ORG where he was to be heard as a witness . He was eventually heard on DATE .
On DATE PERSON was questioned by ORG as a suspect .
A further on - site demonstration , attended by PERSON , was held at TIME on DATE in order to check the visibility conditions .
On DATE ORG submitted information on the visibility conditions at the time of the incident .
On DATE Mr ORG again requested information about the proceedings . On DATE he was informed that the investigation had been completed and that the case had been transferred to ORG .
On DATE ORG preferred a bill of indictment against PERSON charging him with homicide .

On DATE ORG heard PERSON , a witness ( GPE ) , the ambulance doctor , the cameraman and the forensic weapons expert . Mr PERSON had not been notified in advance of this hearing . On the same day PERSON PERSON sent a letter to the presiding judge requesting that he be notified about the date of the next hearing . In his reply the presiding judge dismissed the request on the ground that PERSON PERSON and his client , Mr PERSON 's mother , could not be regarded as a party to the criminal proceedings in accordance with sections DATE CARDINAL of LAW .
Nevertheless , the judge informed PERSON of the dates of the subsequent hearings .
At TIME on DATE ORG conducted an on - site inspection of the scene of the incident .
The next hearing was held on DATE . The reporter , another journalist , the eye - witness ORG , CARDINAL police officers and PERSON accomplice were heard as witnesses .
Another hearing was held on DATE . On that occasion CARDINAL police officers and the ambulance assistant were heard as witnesses .

At the next hearing on DATE the forensic medical expert and the weapons expert were heard . The parties presented their closing arguments . The public prosecutor proposed that PERSON be acquitted by virtue of section CARDINAL ) of LAW . He argued that the defendant should not be punished because he had been acting lawfully in self - defence even though he had exceeded the necessary force ( elhárítás szükséges mértékének túllépése ) in the circumstances . According to the public prosecutor , PERSON could not have assessed properly the situation with which he was confronted on account of his fear and , given the circumstances , his over - reaction was justified . The public prosecutor however observed that the lawfulness of the use of a firearm in itself did not preclude the commission of a crime and referred to sections CARDINAL ) and PERSON ) of LAW in this connection .

Counsel for the defence pleaded that ORG should be acquitted primarily on the ground of the absence of any danger to society and hence the absence of a crime or , alternatively , by reason of lawful self - defence .

On DATE ORG acquitted PERSON , applying section ORG ) of LAW . The court found it impossible to determine whether Mr GPE had been armed at the time of the incident . In particular , it remained unclear whether Mr GPE or his accomplice had had an object in their hands and , if so , whether that object had been a knife , the stolen radio or an object which the offenders had been using to smash the car window . The court observed that the knife apparently found during the inspection of the scene had been lost and could no longer be located in police storage .

Moreover , the court , relying on the opinions of the weapons expert and the CARDINAL forensic pathologists , considered it proven that Mr GPE had been shot while leaning or moving forward , rather than standing or hiding . Given that it was almost completely dark at the time of the incident , the court accepted that PERSON could not properly decipher Mr PERSON 's intention when the latter moved towards him .

ORG was satisfied that the defendant 's action did not constitute a crime . Under sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) of LAW , he had been free to use his gun to avert an attack directed against his life or bodily integrity . His action had therefore not been “ materially illegal ” ( materiális jogellenesség ) , that is , dangerous to society . In these circumstances , no criminal act had been committed – a conclusion which allowed the court to dispense with the examination of the question of self - defence , in particular whether it was lawful self - defence or excessive .

The public prosecutor appealed against this judgment , requesting that the defendant be acquitted under section CARDINAL ) of LAW . Subsequently , the public prosecutor withdrew the appeal . Consequently , on DATE ORG judgment became final .

On DATE Mr ORG requested a copy of ORG judgment . On DATE Mr ORG , submitting a power of attorney signed by the applicant on DATE , requested a copy of the case file from ORG . He stated that the case file was needed in order to introduce an application with ORG . On DATE ORG dismissed PERSON ORG 's request on the ground that the applicant had not been a party to the criminal proceedings . On DATE Mr ORG appealed against this decision . He relied on the LAW and made references to the ORG 's case - law under LAW in criminal proceedings .

On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal holding that there was no connection between the cases referred to and the applicant 's request for a copy of the case file . It was satisfied that the rejection of the request did not hinder the applicant 's exercise of her right to lodge an application with ORG .

( CARDINAL ) Liability for damage caused in the sphere of ORG administration shall be established only if the damage could not have been be prevented by ordinary legal remedies or if the injured party has had recourse to ordinary legal remedies appropriate for preventing the damage .
( CARDINAL ) These rules shall also apply to liability for damage caused in the judicial and prosecution spheres , unless otherwise provided by statute .

( CARDINAL ) Any person who does an act which is necessary in order to prevent an unlawful attack against himself or another person , his own goods , or those of other persons , or against the public interest , or an unlawful attack directly threatening the above , shall not be liable to punishment .

( CARDINAL ) A person shall not be punished either if he exceeds the necessary measure of prevention because he is unable to appreciate it due to fear or justifiable excitement ( menthető felindulás ) .
( CARDINAL ) The punishment may , without limitation , be mitigated if the perpetrator is restricted in appreciating the necessary degree of prevention through fear or justifiable excitement .

( CARDINAL ) A criminal act is an act perpetrated intentionally or DATE if the law also punishes negligent perpetration – by negligence , which is dangerous to society and in respect of which the law imposes punishment .
( CARDINAL ) An act or omission shall be deemed an act of danger to society if it violates or endangers the ORG , the social or economic order of GPE , a person or the rights of citizens .
( CARDINAL ) The actions of the police shall not be such as to cause prejudice which is clearly disproportionate to the legitimate aim of the action .

( CARDINAL ) If there exists several possible and appropriate actions or coercive measures in a given situation , the act or measure chosen should be the CARDINAL which , besides ensuring efficiency , entails the least restriction , injury or damage to the person concerned .
( CARDINAL ) During police actions , in the application of coercive measures , the infliction of injuries or deprivation of life should be avoided as far as possible . ...
A police officer may use his firearm : ...
( k ) in order to avert an attack directed against his own life , bodily integrity or personal freedom .
( CARDINAL ) A victim is a party whose rights or lawful interests have been infringed or endangered by the offence .
( CARDINAL ) The victim :
( a ) may be present at any procedural acts carried out during the investigation , provided that the victim 's presence is permitted by LAW , or during the trial , unless this LAW states otherwise ;
( b ) may have access to documents concerning him / her after the conclusion of the investigation ,
( c ) may , at any stage of the proceedings , file motions or observations , and request information on his / her procedural rights and obligations ,
( d ) may submit questions to be put to those heard at the hearing and may take the floor .
( CARDINAL ) A civil party is a victim who files a civil - law claim for determination in the criminal proceedings .

( CARDINAL ) In the event of the victim 's death , his / her heir may become a civil party . However , the rights set out in section CARDINAL will be applicable only in relation to the proof of the civil - law claim .

( CARDINAL ) If possible , the court shall decide on the merits of the civil - law claim in the judgment or decision terminating the criminal proceedings . If this procedure delays the criminal proceedings significantly , the court may redirect the civil - law claim to other courts .
( CARDINAL ) Copies of documents from the criminal case - files shall be issued to the ... civil party ... and his / her representative at their request .
